Posts.Title: Got some bad news today

Posts.Content: I'm sorry, but I'm with Kate on this.   Steve Jobs didn't believe in conventional medicine, and I'm afraid it didn't end well for him.   Unless the lump is totally out, you are not going to know completely what stage you are at. I don't mean to scare you, but it could be worse.   My initial diagnosis was DCIS and  despite being enlarged my lymph nodes tested negative. I opted for a mastectomy and when everything was tested in full, it was found that I had 2 invasive carcinomas, stage 2 and 3, and in fact, 3 of 16 lymph nodes were found to be positive for tumour cells.   They cannot tell everything from a biopsy because they are looking for such tiny cells and it is impossible to tell without disecting the whole thing.   However, I do appreciate that it is bloody scary and a horrid idea - having part of your breast cut away, but the surgeons and whole Multi Disciplinary Team do know what they are doing. It won't just be one person assessing you, it will be the whole team.   If you aren't sure then a 2nd opinion might be a good idea.   To be honest, I don't fancy the side effects that will come with the chemo, RT, tamoxifen, and Herceptin that I am about to have, but I prefer the CHANCE of having the side effects, or not, as the case may be, to the other option, which is death.   I know what I have said is harsh, but in some ways it is pretty cut and dried.   Best of luck making your decision.   LM x
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Annie   It's hard not to let this horrid disease take over isn't it?   Sorry you're having such a hard time.   My understanding is that they'll somethimes use chemo to shrink a lump before operating (this is standard in the US) - to try to save the breast, but as far as I know if this isn't possible, (in my case it wasn't due to size of lump compared to breast, and distribution of micro-calcifications in all 4 quadrants) then they will operate.   It's clearly making you very worried, and I would be the same. When is your appointment? I'd be asking (if it were me) what the next stage is, and probably, whether they'd recommend a lumpectomy or mastectomy.   I'm sure that they have a plan in place though, to make sure they kick the cancer's arse so you can get your life back.   Don't forget, that it is your body though, and if you have a preference, they have to take it into account.   Take care   LM x   PS - if you want an appointment sooner, never be afraid to ask for one/keep chasing up.

Posts.Content: Tinkers, I really think (and I do not want to get into a row) that you are over simplifying things. Just because I eat  meat doesn't mean that my body is going to absorb all of that animals hormones which will then have a domino effect on my own. It just isn't that simple. Do you have a scientific background? We use a huge range of ingredients, and there is nothing in terms of ingredients that specifically targets the reproductive potential of the animals, and it is the same whichever animal you look at. All we do is (and we do make our own feed) make feed that promotes general growth, i.e. has the correct levels of protein, carbs etc in. Nothing is targeted at increasing the reproductive capacity of an animal. My cancer is also E+, and I have no intention of becoming vegetarian. Meat is perfectly safe to eat, in MODERATION, like everything else. We are omnivores, and designed to eat meat. It is not natural for us to exlude a particular food source from our diets. How do you monitor your hormone levels by the way? Do you have regular testing to ascertain what they are and adjust your food intake accordingly? Do you just drink bottled water? There is no evidence that avoiding dairy products will lessen chances of getting cancer/cancer recurring. Do you only eat fish that is fished from the wild rather than farmed? Where do you draw the line?
Posts.Title: Parabens

Posts.Content: Buying Parabens free cosmetics etc is a good, positive thing to do, but I just have to comment about meat - can't remember who posted earlier about meat being injected with growth hormones... but, it is utter rubbish.   We have a pig farm, and our pigs do not go anywhere near any sort of growth hormone, despite the fact we are not organic farmers.   If you buy BRITISH meat, you will be fine - none of the animals in this country get growth hormones.   If you buy meat from any other country in the world, it is not fed and reared to the same standards as our animals in the UK (welfare etc), and many other countries use growth hormones.   There is nothing wrong with eating meat in moderation, like everything else. Just make sure it is BRITISH.
Posts.Title: Parabens

Posts.Content: Hi Coot   I had mine on 31st August and was a day patient - had the op at 10.30 am and left at 7.30pm - could have left earlier but my husband put the children to bed first. They were flexible though - if I had wanted to stay in I could have done. They won't leave a drain in (well, it is unusual to these days). Mx bra - no need. I bought some cheap crop tops from Sainsburys which have been fabulous. I've also found that nursing bras are great at holding the soft prosthesis in, so I haven't bought any yet. I had some lymph nodes removed at the same time and am waiting to hear if I need any more out - had the Sentinel node test during op. Looking at the gap is fine for the first week or so - there is a full dressing on (waterproof, so you can shower) so there is nothing to see. I am also squeemish and not looking forward to having the whole lot off on Tuesday. To be honest, I think my motto is going to be "don't look down". I had wondered whether I could live without a breast on one side, but there's no way I can, so I also keep telling myself that it is only temporary. If it helps at all, I have had no pain with it at all. I had cording before the op due to lymph node biopsies that that gives more pain when I reach for things. The exercises do help though. I took paracetamol and ibuprofen as recommended on Saturday and Sunday last week, then eased off the paracetamol on Monday - didn't notice any different and have only been taking the ibuprofen since - due to it's anti inflammatory skills rather than pain relief. I've also had no swelling. Hope that helps a bit. I have taken some photos to try and make me get to grips with it all. It's scary as hell, but I keep telling myself that cancer is scarier.   Take care and good luck with the op   LM x
